Nigguṇḍi’s Flower Elder’s Birth Story
“When a god falls from the god-realm,
at the end of his life,
three sounds arise,
to the delight of the gods.

analyzed: itas bho sugatim gaccha  manussānam sahabyata
translated: ‘Go from here, sir, to a good destination,🔽to companionship with human beings.
As a human being, in the true Teaching,
attain the unsurpassed faith.
That faith of yours will be firmly established,
rooted and grounded,
as long as you live, without wavering,
in the true Teaching, well-proclaimed.
Having done good by body,
and much good by speech,
and having done good by mind,
without violence, without attachment,🔽then, having made much merit,
through giving, with that attachment,
establish other people too in the true Teaching,
in the spiritual life.’🔽When the gods, the gods of the gods,
saw this compassion,
they rejoiced,
saying, ‘Come, god, again and again.’
‘I was then moved to tears,
when the assembly of gods had gathered.
What kind of womb
will I go to, having fallen from here?’
Understanding my distress,
the monk with developed faculties,
desiring to rescue me,
came into my presence.
His name was Sumana,
a disciple of Padumuttara;
Having instructed me in the meaning of the Dhamma,
he then inspired me with this verse.
The twelfth recitation-section.
Having heard his words,
I developed confidence in the Buddha;
Having paid homage to that sage,
I died right there.
I was reborn right there,
urged on by the root of merit;
Dwelling in my mother’s womb,
I was again carried by my mother.
Having fallen from that state,🔽I was reborn in the same place;
In the meantime I did not see
any mental unhappiness.
Having fallen from the Tāvatiṁsa,
I entered my mother’s womb;
Having emerged from the womb,
I did not know black from white.
At the age of seven years,
I entered the monastery;
Of the Fortunate One, the Buddha,
the Sakyan, the Worthy One, the Tathāgata.
In the expanding Dispensation,
in the teaching of the Great Man,
I saw the monks there,
who were carrying out the Teacher’s instructions.
The city was called Sāvatthī,
and the king there was Kosala;
With a chariot yoked with elephants,
he approached the supreme Bodhi tree.

analyzed: tassa aham nāgam disvāna  pubba kammam anussari
translated: Having seen the elephant there,🔽I remembered my past deeds;
I raised my hands in respectful salutation,
and I went to the assembly.
At the age of seven years,
I went forth into homelessness;
The one who attended to the Buddha,

analyzed: ānandaḥ nāma sāvakaḥ  gatimā dhitimā ca iva
translated: the disciple named Ānanda.🔽He was one of great wisdom, great mindfulness,
and great learning;
Delighting the king’s mind,
he sent forth great radiance.
Having heard the Dhamma from him,
I remembered my past deeds;
Standing right there,
I attained perfection.
Having arranged my robe over one shoulder,
and raising my joined palms to my head,
I paid homage to the Fully Awakened One,🔽and uttered this speech:
‘To the Buddha Padumuttara,
the leader of the two-footed, the Teacher,
I offered a Nigguṇḍi flower,
placing it on the lion throne.
By that deed, leader of the two-footed,
the chief in the world, the bull among men;
I have attained the unshakable state,
having abandoned victory and defeat.’
In twenty-five thousand eons,
monarchs of the humans,
the Abbudas and the Anāthapiṇḍakas,
were eight times kings.
